description: From Middle English medle, from Anglo-Norman medlee, Old French medlee, from the feminine past participle of early Medieval Latin misculō (“to mix”). Compare meddle. Doublet of melee.

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic) Combat, fighting; a battle. [from 14thc.]
examples: For greater shields they have, than that they can either doe or see ought, and being raunged by hundreds no doubt they will hinder one another in the medley, except some very few

entries.meaning: A collection or mixture of miscellaneous things. [from 17thc.]
(music) A collection of related songs played or mixed together as a single piece. [from 17thc.]
examples: They played a medley of favorite folk songs as an encore.

entries.meaning: (swimming) A competitive swimming event that combines the four strokes of butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle. [from 20th c.]

examples: Otherwise , as our Saviour noteth , when the old Cloth was joyned to the new , it made no good medley , but the Rent was made the wors

verbs.description: medley (third-person singular simple present medleys, present participle medleying, simple past and past participle medleyed)

entries.meaning: (music) To combine, to form a medley.
